â
The '''Galaxy Nexus''' is a [[touchscreen]] [[slate phone|slate]] [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[smartphone]] developed by a partnership between [[Samsung]] and [[Google]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/samsung-and-google-introduce-galaxy-nexus-2011-10-18|title=Samsung and Google introduce GALAXY Nexus|publisher=[[MarketWatch]]|date=October 19, 2011}}</ref> The phone and operating system were developed collaboratively by engineers from both companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9220984/Samsung_Google_unveil_latest_Android_OS_phone|title=Samsung, Google unveil latest Android OS, phone|publisher=''[[Computerworld]]''|date=October 19, 2011|accessdate=October 19, 2011}}</ref> It is the third generation successor to Googleâs previous flagship phones, the [[Nexus One]] and [[Nexus S]]. It has an entirely new design and includes a host of hardware and software upgrades including a curved HD (1280Ã720 pixels)<ref>[http://www.gsmarena.com/samsung_galaxy_nexus-4219.php Samsung Galaxy Nexus â Full phone specifications]. Gsmarena.com. Retrieved on 2011-11-21.</ref> Super [[AMOLED]] display, an improved camera system, and Googleâs new version of its Android operating system, version 4.0, codenamed ''Ice Cream Sandwich''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/18/samsungs-galaxy-nexus-gets-official-android-4-0-4-65-inch-hd|title=Samsung's Galaxy Nexus gets official: Android 4.0, 4.65-inch HD Super AMOLED display (video)|publisher=[[Engadget]]|date=October 18, 2011}}</ref> Before the official announcement, it was also referred to as the Google Nexus Prime among Android enthusiasts and the media.<ref>http://www.theverge.com/2011/11/10/2552250/this-is-my-next-galaxy-nexus</ref><ref>http://gigaom.com/mobile/android-this-week-nexus-prime-launches-tablet-sales-data-android-4-0-arrives/</ref> The name is the result of [[co-branding]] between the ''Samsung Galaxy'' and ''[[Google Nexus]]'' brands of Android smartphones.
+
The '''Galaxy Nexus''' is a [[touchscreen]] [[slate phone|slate]] [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[smartphone]] developed by a partnership between [[Samsung]] and [[Google]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/samsung-and-google-introduce-galaxy-nexus-2011-10-18|title=Samsung and Google introduce GALAXY Nexus|publisher=[[MarketWatch]]|date=October 19, 2011}}</ref> The phone and operating system were developed collaboratively by engineers from both companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9220984/Samsung_Google_unveil_latest_Android_OS_phone|title=Samsung, Google unveil latest Android OS, phone|publisher=''[[Computerworld]]''|date=October 19, 2011|accessdate=October 19, 2011}}</ref> It is the third generation successor to Googleâs previous flagship phones, the [[Nexus One]] and [[Nexus S]]. It has an entirely new design and includes a host of hardware and software upgrades including a curved HD (1280Ã720 pixels)<ref>[http://www.gsmarena.com/samsung_galaxy_nexus-4219.php Samsung Galaxy Nexus â Full phone specifications]. Gsmarena.com. Retrieved on 2011-11-21.</ref> Super [[AMOLED]] display, an improved camera system, and Googleâs new version of its Android operating system, version 4.0, codenamed ''Ice Cream Sandwich''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/18/samsungs-galaxy-nexus-gets-official-android-4-0-4-65-inch-hd|title=Samsung's Galaxy Nexus gets official: Android 4.0, 4.65-inch HD Super AMOLED display (video)|publisher=[[Engadget]]|date=October 18, 2011}}</ref> Before the official announcement, it was also referred to as the Google Nexus Prime among Android enthusiasts and the media.<ref>{{cite web|last=Topolsky |first=Joshua |url=http://www.theverge.com/2011/11/10/2552250/this-is-my-next-galaxy-nexus |title=This is my next: the Galaxy Nexus |publisher=The Verge |date=2011-11-10 |accessdate=2011-11-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gigaom.com/mobile/android-this-week-nexus-prime-launches-tablet-sales-data-android-4-0-arrives/ |title=Android this week: Nexus Prime launches; tablet sales data; Android 4.0 arrives â Mobile Technology News |publisher=Gigaom.com |date=2011-10-22 |accessdate=2011-11-22}}</ref> The name is the result of [[co-branding]] between the ''Samsung Galaxy'' and ''[[Google Nexus]]'' brands of Android smartphones.
The Galaxy Nexus was unveiled at Google and Samsung's ''Ice Cream Sandwich'' event on 19 October, 2011 in [[Hong Kong]]. It was released on November, 17, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gizmodo.com/5851133/samsung-galaxy-nexus-the-greatest-androids-got-a-720p-super-amoled-display|title=This Is the Samsung Galaxy Nexus, Googleâs New Official Android Phone|work=Gizmodo}}</ref> [[Amazon.com|Amazon UK]] has confirmed they will be selling the Galaxy Nexus starting on December 2, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.co.uk/Samsung-Galaxy-Nexus-16GB-Smartphone/dp/B005XYU45E|title=Samsung Galaxy Nexus 16GB Sim Free Smartphone|work=Amazon.com}}</ref>
The Galaxy Nexus was unveiled at Google and Samsung's ''Ice Cream Sandwich'' event on 19 October, 2011 in [[Hong Kong]]. It was released on November, 17, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gizmodo.com/5851133/samsung-galaxy-nexus-the-greatest-androids-got-a-720p-super-amoled-display|title=This Is the Samsung Galaxy Nexus, Googleâs New Official Android Phone|work=Gizmodo}}</ref> [[Amazon.com|Amazon UK]] has confirmed they will be selling the Galaxy Nexus starting on December 2, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.co.uk/Samsung-Galaxy-Nexus-16GB-Smartphone/dp/B005XYU45E|title=Samsung Galaxy Nexus 16GB Sim Free Smartphone|work=Amazon.com}}</ref>

== Hardware ==
== Hardware ==
â
The Galaxy Nexus features a 4.65-inch 1280Ã720-pixel HD [[Super AMOLED]] [[PenTile]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slashgear.com/galaxy-nexus-has-curved-pentile-oled-display-21189996 |title=Galaxy Nexus has curved PenTile OLED display |publisher=SlashGear |date= |accessdate=2011-10-27}}</ref> curved glass display,<ref name="engadget20111006"/> a dual-core 1.2 GHz [[Texas Instruments OMAP|TI OMAP]] 4460 processor (ARM Cortex-A9)<ref name="bgr20111006"/> with an accompanying [[PowerVR]] SGX540,<ref>[http://focus.ti.com/general/docs/wtbu/wtbuproductcontent.tsp?contentId=53243&navigationId=12843&templateId=6123 OMAPâ¢ 4 Platform: OMAP4430/OMAP4460]. Focus.ti.com. Retrieved on 2011-11-21.</ref> 1 GB of RAM. The processor can run from 1.2â1.5 GHz, but is underclocked at 1.2 GHz for smooth performance. However, it can easily run at 1.5 GHz once rooted (see [[Texas_Instruments_OMAP#OMAP_4|Texas Instruments OMAP]]). Additionally, a 1,750 [[Ampere-hour|mAh]] battery, 1.3 MP front camera and 5 MP rear camera (with zero shutter lag<ref>[http://terrrra.com/?q=zero%20shutter%20lag%20nexus%20prime Search Online]. Terrrra.com. Retrieved on 2011-11-21.</ref>) capable of [[1080p]] video,<ref>[http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/19/samsung-galaxy-nexus-camera-and-1080p-video-samples/ Samsung Galaxy Nexus camera and 1080p video samples]. Engadget. Retrieved on 2011-11-21.</ref> [[4G]], [[Wi-Fi]] a/b/g/n, [[Bluetooth]], [[Global Positioning System|GPS]], [[barometer]], and [[Near field communication|NFC]]<ref name="brighthand18084"/> and it has 16 or 32 GB of internal memory.<ref>[http://www.shugalmela.com/samsung-galaxy-nexus-reviews-and-specification/ Samsung Galaxy Nexus internal memory]. Shugalmela.com (2011-10-20). Retrieved on 2011-11-21.</ref>
+

The Galaxy Nexus also hosts support for [[Mobile High-definition Link|MHL]] through the use of its [[Micro USB]] [[USB|2.0]] port.<ref name="mhl endgadget">{{cite web |url=http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/20/behind-the-glass-a-detailed-tour-inside-the-samsung-galaxy-nexu/ |title=Behind the glass: a detailed tour inside the Samsung Galaxy Nexus |first=Brad |last=Molen |date=20 October 2011 |accessdate=24 October 2011 |work=Engadget}}</ref>

According to [[Engadget]] editor Darren Murph, the Galaxy Nexus was "smooth as ever. Without question, this is easily the slickest, most polished version of Android yet"<ref>[http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/19/google-ice-cream-sandwich-android-4-0-a-hands-on-screenshot-g/ Google Ice Cream Sandwich (Android 4.0): a hands-on screenshot gallery]. Engadget. Retrieved on 2011-11-21.</ref> and that "The entire experience just felt polished. In a way, it's as if Android's growing a bit and maturing before our eyes", concluding with "Overall, we're thrilled with how the first [[Android version history#4.x Ice Cream Sandwich|ICS]] handset has turned out. It's understated, sleek, beautiful and packs a display that's destined to drop jaws."<ref>[http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/18/samsung-galaxy-nexus-hands-on/ Samsung Galaxy Nexus with Ice Cream Sandwich hands-on (video)]. Engadget. Retrieved on 2011-11-21.</ref>
+
According to [[Engadget]] editor Darren Murph, the Galaxy Nexus was "smooth as ever. Without question, this is easily the slickest, most polished version of Android yet"<ref>[http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/19/google-ice-cream-sandwich-android-4-0-a-hands-on-screenshot-g/ Google Ice Cream Sandwich (Android 4.0): a hands-on screenshot gallery]. Engadget. Retrieved on 2011-11-21.</ref> and that "The entire experience just felt polished. In a way, it's as if Android's growing a bit and maturing before our eyes", concluding with "Overall, we're thrilled with how the first [[Ice Cream Sandwich (operating system)|ICS]] handset has turned out. It's understated, sleek, beautiful and packs a display that's destined to drop jaws."<ref>[http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/18/samsung-galaxy-nexus-hands-on/ Samsung Galaxy Nexus with Ice Cream Sandwich hands-on (video)]. Engadget. Retrieved on 2011-11-21.</ref>
In a [[T3 (magazine)|T3]] review Thomas Tamblyn noted the camera was "quicker than many digital cameras" and concluded saying "the whole experience is very fluid. Even in its current form [a pre-release version] It feels like a version of Android that is already very polished."<ref>{{cite web|author=Updated 18:31 26 Oct 2011 by Thomas Tamblyn |url=http://www.t3.com/reviews/samsung-galaxy-nexus-review |title=Samsung Galaxy Nexus review: Hands on |publisher=T3 |date= |accessdate=2011-10-27}}</ref>

Even in its current form [a pre-release version] It feels like a version of Android that is already very polished."<ref>{{cite web|author=Updated 18:31 26 Oct 2011 by Thomas Tamblyn |url=http://www.t3.com/reviews/samsung-galaxy-nexus-review |title=Samsung Galaxy Nexus review: Hands on |publisher=T3 |date= |accessdate=2011-10-27}}</ref>

Vincent Nguyen, from [[SlashGear]] noted the fast performance of Android 4.0.1, the tight integration between the operating system and the hardware and concluded that "this is the best Android phone around today".<ref>http://www.slashgear.com/galaxy-nexus-review-21196912/</ref>
+
Vincent Nguyen, from [[SlashGear]] noted the fast performance of Android 4.0.1, the tight integration between the operating system and the hardware and concluded that "this is the best Android phone around today".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slashgear.com/galaxy-nexus-review-21196912/ |title=Galaxy Nexus Review |publisher=SlashGear |date=2006-10-27 |accessdate=2011-11-22}}</ref>

== See also ==
